root.pub-comments: Hodge writes that "it is preferable to refer to [Lisramic] as a phylum rather than a family. This reflects present knowledge vis-à-vis relationship" (Hodge 1976:43). The alternate names “are [also] largely part of dialect geography of linguistic terminology: Semito-Hamitic for Eastern Europe; Hamito-Semitic for the rest of Europe; Erythraic in the focal area of the School of Oriental and African Studies, London; Afroasiatic in the US generally; Lisramic and Afrasian still on the door-step waiting to be adopted” (Hodge 1976:43).
root.alt-names: Afrasian, Afro-Asian, Afroasiatic, Erythraic, Hamito-Semitic, Semito-Hamitic
root.publications: Hodge, Carleton T. 1976. Lisramic (Afroasiatic): An Overview, The Non-Semitic Languages of Ethiopia, 43-66. East Lansing: African Study Center.

child.geography: "The Berber languages were formerly spoken throughout North Africa--from the border of Egypt to the Canary Islands--and are now found in enclaves scattered over the continental part of this area" (Hodge: 1976 45).

child.publications: Hodge, Carleton T. 1976. Lisramic (Afroasiatic): An Overview, The Non-Semitic Languages of Ethiopia, 43-66. East Lansing: African Study Center.
child.geography: "The Chadic speech-area centers in northern Nigeria, Southern Chad, and northern Cameroon, spilling into neighboring areas" (Hodge: 1976 45).

child.publications: Hodge, Carleton T. 1976. Lisramic (Afroasiatic): An Overview, The Non-Semitic Languages of Ethiopia, 43-66. East Lansing: African Study Center.
